comments.commentBody:
On the constructive side, the way to help third world countries is to use our technology to develop things which they need but cannot make. The real heroes are the few who develop crops adapted to the conditions from different regions of Africa, resistant to the diseases there and so on - the kind of things our farmers take for granted.

Primitive farming is very sensitive to climate and the associate diseases. Our advanced farming, much less so: wheat is grown from Sweden to Brazil, so farming could adapt even to a (pre Holocene type of) massive climate change.

Not everyone though has access to the seeds and knowledge needed - sharing, or even better custom tailoring farming seeds, knowledge, tools is the best form of help...

PS Contrast that with the UNHELPFUL kind of information. I looked the other day at a Japanese paper in which the main rice varieties from Japan were grown at temperatures 8C higher, with bad results. The study was extremely careful and well documented and published in a prestigious journal. It was picked by the alarmist press.

You can see immediately the fundamental flaw: at 8C temperature increase (way bigger than any climate change) you have to grow DIFFERENT kinds of rice. E.g. in China or the Philippines or India it's 8C warmer than in Japan and the rice crops are doing just fine...

That's the kind of science favored by the IPCC at its best (at its worst it uses rumors). It's done very carefully, it's peer reviewed in prestigious journals but it has a major flaw which invalidates its meaning...

Needless to say, the effect of such work on actual crops in third world countries is absolutely nil.

Because Robertson is probably a transplant as most yuppies are. "From" Park Slope via Kansas or Minnesota.

Henry, Ze Roberto or Ronaldinho would do wonders for our league. People have to remember that MLS is still in its infancy and the caliber of its players, soccer-specific stadiums, growing fan base and expanding league is showing the revelance and sustainability of this fledgling league that is here to stay. The new generation is upon us and soccer is the word.

Sorry, baseball fans.
No, no, no, no, no. Not now, not ever! Isn't there somebody in Buffalo who can hit better than Matthews Jr?
What about Fernando?

Pat Burrell (or even Keith Hernandez) cannot possibly be worse than Gary Mathews, Jr. They should pick him up.

"This team is going to be hilarious to watch!"

Gates BBQ! Get BURNT ENDS!!! Just try it!
3205 Main
Kansas City, MO
816-753-0828
Hours of Operation:
Open everyday 10:00 am until midnight.
Friday and Sat. open 10:00 am until 1:00 am.
Sunday 10:00 am until midnight.

Go there late after doing the jazz thing at the Blue Room on 18th St. Perfect Kansas City experience!

I agree with all of those! Room 39 is a staple. Aixois (right down the street from my house) is sooo good. Also Blue Stem is great as well. What about Michael Smith's though? How could you mention Extra Virgin and not mention Michael Smith?

Further more... it would just be wrong to go to KC and miss out on all of the delicious coffee to be had:
(1) Broadway cafe!!! Amazing..
Crosstown Station
Latte Land (the one by J.Crew on the plaza) is a staple
Hi Hat.. too cute
Coffee Girls
... and how could you tell people to go to 17th/18th and Baltimore to check out the shops and not mention YJs?

(2) Christopher Elbow! His chocolate is beyond good and he's opening up an ice cream place on 51st street near main st.

Speaking of Ice cream... how could you miss Murray's in Westport.

Seriously.
So many great places were overlooked.
Gotta do coffee at the biggest little coffeeshop in the country......Hi Hat Coffee, 5012 State Line Road.  wow.

We are enjoying our vacation on Kauai.  We've been returning every May since our first trip in 2002.  We now stay here in Poipu since friends referred us to Coastline Cottages.  Beautiful island.  Excellent accommodations. White sand beaches.  Warm clean ocean.  We rented bikes from Outfitters Kauai this year and are enjoying easy bike rides along Poipu's coast.
"Rugged" is all I have to say about the clue for 12 Down - they totally got me.  I join in the ode!
Matt: Funny. But to my point, in this day and age not everyone has a printer at home. No need. Everything can be done online. Thanks for getting the Across Lite working.

ok....please don't kick me out for being all cheerful...but wow i LOVED this. Matt, i feel awful for you after such a brilliant construction... You created a superb puzzle!

I have to say....for me, personally, this was a huge pleasure to print this out and take off to Tim Horton's, get an extra large steeped tea to sit in a corner and figure this out. Loved the mystery of not knowing what what it entailed (oy, i even used a pencil for once, just to be safe) and just loved the aha moment : ) Jim, bless your heart for figuring out an online version for those who had the screaming meemies - way to go! (I did feel badly for the lady with arthritis...) Amy, I'm with you, I would go for the fresh challenge over pure convention also. But everyone's taste is different, i realize that....

Finally, don't retire Will!!! We love you! - well most of us do anyway : ) : )

You know, I didn't much like the puzzle either and I was all set to unload on it  Even granting the 'double cross' ingenuity, I found the puzzle tiresome.  But after reading the negative comments here, they're over the top.  Come on guys, it's only a puzzle.  It's only one week.  It was an interesting idea that didn't pan out.  With luck, tomorrow will be better.
Addenda: TIMEWARNER TIMEWASTER just cracked me up!

Well, I liked it. I don't go for speed anyway, and usually print out the weekend puzzles for myself and for my husband, so I didn't mind.

Anyway, it was strange, but I enjoyed doing it. I did give a tip to my husband: don't worry about the special clues, just do everything else you can around them, and it will be easier to figure out the answers (and the gimmick) after a bunch of other crosswords are filled in.
I loved this puzzle!  It was very clever and lots of fun!  No complaints whatsoever from me!  Thank you very much, Matt!

shame on you Will

you violated an implicit contract to play fair with readers just so you could gloat at your own cleverness. You deserve every cross word you get and worse. Maybe you should take a sabbatical if you are so bored with delivering a straightforward quality product. Or perhaps your masters at NYT will wise up to the fact people are paying for good puzzles, not your arrogance.

I thought some of the comments were unusually harsh.  I print the puzzles and do them in pencil, and yes, this one was a bit unwieldy, but how about some kudos to Matt Ginsberg for great brainpower and imagination.

since when does being a paying customer give you the right to be unconscionably rude?

i loved the puzzle, but even if i didn't, i'd probably keep my complaints to myself. the new york times crossword is a feature of the new york times, which is a newsPAPER. the vast majority of solvers still do it in print. if you're a premium subscriber, you can still access the puzzle and print it out. nobody's denying you a crossword.

Oh, lord, I hate to be a whiner, but even though I completed and thoroughly enjoyed the puzzle on paper, I went to the new Across Lite version out of curiousity, and now I'm confused about what it means to go to the note pad. What is the notepad and how does one access it?

Now, about this puzzle. I thought it was wickedly clever, especially at the crossings that used four different letters. Generally speaking it wasn't that hard, but I did get seriously hung up in the area of FIT TO KILL. That's not an expression I'm familiar with, and unfortunately few of the crosses gave me much help. Having ERRors instead of ERRATA for a while didn't help any. Also, I was sure that the Bozo clue was pointing to something about his red hair: reDDER, for example. I had to put the puzzle down for a while before finishing that section.

I hope everyone finally got to enjoy this one. It was a good one.
as good as ever, try the whole snapper in salt

I always print the puzzle anyway and do it with a pen on a clip board, but tonight I had two pages.  Clues on the first, and grid on the second, forcing me to flip from one sheet to another.  Not fun, despite the cleverness of the theme.  As I started working this thing my only thought was that everyone was going to go freaking bananas.  Wow, was I right on that.

Good grief. NYT cry babies.. Y'all would really rather lose great puzzle designs to other markets because they aren’t stamped out like every other before going into the COOKIE COOKER? This is a tour de force.

Clues and entries are backed into a conservative corner already. I can only surmise that many solvers don't have a perspective of what is available beyond the NYT if unable to cope with this fine puzzle.

I agree 100% with Amy Reynaldo. Except for the fact that my right hand hurts a bit b/c it's been years since I used it to actually wield a...whaddaya call it...oh, yeah--a pen, I took it on faith that, with Will at the helm, the need to go PDF would be worth it--and in my opinion it was. Awesome job, Will and Matt.
Buffet lunch in 'Once Upon a Time' in Hotel Green Park is superb. More than twenty deserts are served.
